title: 114_s2932
content: The Act may be cited as the "Protecting Patient Access to Emergency Medications Act of 2016". The Congress recognizes the importance of controlled substances for emergency medical services to save lives and improve health outcomes. Mobile emergency medical services require time-sensitive care for critical injuries and illnesses in the field. There have been few DEA investigations related to diversion in emergency medical services. Regulatory oversight is crucial to prevent diversion of controlled substances in emergency medical services. Recent surveys show minimal diversions or investigations despite a large number of doses administered. Oversight should be tailored to unique care delivery models, including supervision by a physician medical director. Regulatory oversight in all healthcare settings, including emergency medical services, should be tailored to unique care delivery models and promote uniformity of rules to prevent diversion of controlled substances. This oversight should recognize the variety of emergency medical services agencies. SEC. 312 of the Controlled Substances Act adds regulations for emergency medical services. SEC. 312 of the Controlled Substances Act defines key terms related to emergency medical services, including emergency medical services, emergency medical services agency, and emergency medical services practitioner. The Controlled Substances Act defines terms related to emergency medical services, including emergency medical services practitioner, medical director, medical oversight, and standing order. The Controlled Substances Act defines terms related to emergency medical services, including medical director, medical oversight, standing order, verbal order, and online medical direction. The Controlled Substances Act defines terms related to emergency medical services, including verbal order, online medical direction, and registrant emergency medical services agency. The Controlled Substances Act defines a registrant emergency medical services agency as an agency or hospital that registers to dispense controlled substances for emergency medical services. The agency can register under its own hospital license instead of registering individual practitioners. The Attorney General can register emergency medical services agencies under section 303(f) instead of registering individual practitioners or medical directors. A single registration per State is required, not for each location of the agency. Guidance provided to registrants should recognize the existing delivery of medical care. The Attorney General can register emergency medical services agencies under section 303(f) instead of registering individual practitioners or medical directors. Each agency needs separate registration for each location. Guidance provided should recognize existing medical care delivery and service models. Medical oversight is required with one or more medical directors responsible. Medical oversight for emergency medical services agencies requires one or more licensed physicians to oversee the provision of services, with responsibilities delegated by the state or its authorities. The medical director of an emergency medical services agency, under state or delegated authority, has responsibilities including decisions on patient transportation, approving medical protocols, and overseeing patient care provided by practitioners. The medical director of an emergency medical services agency oversees patient care, including evaluation, treatment, interventions, online medical direction, drug formularies, medication dispensing, and administering. They also manage medical education and training programs for practitioners. The medical director oversees patient care, drug formularies, medication dispensing, administering, medical education, training programs, and quality improvement for the emergency medical services agency. Controlled substances in schedule II-V may be administered by EMS practitioners. Controlled substances in schedule II-V may be administered by emergency medical services practitioners under standing orders or online medical direction from medical directors or licensed physicians. Emergency medical services practitioners can receive verbal orders from medical directors in specific circumstances, such as for individual patients or during mass casualty incidents. Medical directors can provide verbal orders to emergency medical services practitioners in specific patient situations or during mass casualty incidents. The medical directors are not limited in prescribing controlled substances in these cases. Medical directors of emergency medical services agencies can administer controlled substances without being present or providing a prescription for a known individual. The agency must keep standing orders on file and provide them to the Attorney General upon request. The registrant emergency medical services agency must keep standing orders on file and make them available to the Attorney General upon request. A policy requiring documentation of verbal orders and controlled substance administration in patient care charts must be in place. Controlled substance administration must be documented promptly and made available to the Attorney General upon request. The registrant emergency medical services agency must document the administration of controlled substances in patient care charts promptly. Controlled substances can only be received at designated locations and can be moved or delivered within the agency's possession. The registrant emergency medical services agency can receive, move, deliver, and store controlled substances at designated locations only. Movement or delivery of controlled substances within the agency's possession does not classify the agency as a distributor under the Act. The registrant emergency medical services agency can store controlled substances at designated locations only, not at any other location. This section does not affect requirements under titles XVIII or XIX of the Social Security Act or limit the Attorney General's authority to enforce diversion of controlled substances.
